item.title: El Cortez Hotel and Casino: A Downtown Las Vegas Landmark Through the Decades | Vintage Vegas History
item.description:
A Pioneer on Fremont: The El Cortez Opens Its Doors

The year was 1941. The world was on the brink of war, but in Las Vegas, a different kind of excitement was brewing. On November 7th, the El Cortez Hotel and Casino officially opened its doors, joining a fledgling collection of casinos along Fremont Street. Originally owned by Jim Cortese (hence the name “El Cortez”), the hotel offered a modest 60 rooms, a crucial difference from the rapidly expanding establishments further down the nascent Las Vegas Strip. It wasnâ€™t flashy or grand, but it represented a vital part of the early Las Vegas landscape: accessible, straightforward gaming and lodging for a growing population of tourists.
